summary: The U.S. District Court for the Western District of Utah yesterday entered a final judgment against Wilson, finding him liable for a second-degree felony and ordering him to pay a $1,000 civil penalty.  The SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in Salt Lake City, Utah, alleges that Wilson made a series of false statements to a jury during the course of the trial, including that he had engaged in a "jealous lover" defense, that he was prepared to kill a woman, and that he would "handle shit on my own."  Wilson also allegedly told the jury that, during a verbal altercation leading up to the stabbing, he had "jumped in the car with me as if [he] was going to hurt me."  According to the complaint, Wilson replied to one of the jury members by saying, “I gotta think of a good reason as to why my life was in danger.”  The complaint further alleges that, when Wilson returned to the house for a visit, he told another woman that he "was excited about having a baby in the same way."  In addition, Wilson allegedly told one of his co-defendants that, if he didn’t get his way, the baby would be different because he would have had somewhere more permanent to lay his head for nine months.  In a parallel action, the United States Attorney’s Office for the Southern District of New York today announced criminal charges against Wilson.  Without admitting or denying the allegations of the SEC, Wilson consented to the entry of a judgment that permanently enjoins him from future violations of the antifraud provisions of Section 17(a) of the Securities Act of 1933, Section 10(b) the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder, and Sections 206(1), 206(2), and 206(4)-8 of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 and Rule 206(3)-8 thereunder.  Wilson has also agreed to a settlement where he will be permanently enjoined from violating the charged provisions of the federal securities laws, with the right to return the allegedly ill-gotten gains to his family and to the institution of his law license.   The settlement is subject to court approval.  On May 2, 2019, the SEC filed a civil injunctive action against Wilson in federal district court in Utah against him, charging him with violating Section 5 of the Exchange Act and Rule 5a-14 thereunder; and against Girlfriend and her father, who are charged with aiding and abetting Wilson's violations of Section 15(a)(1) and (3) of
